Review title: Bollywood viewers need an honest review
Review_body: This movie is totally hyped due to an ultimate sacrifice made by Mr Bikram Batra. The character development is unnecessarily dramatized to the extend that it looks unreal because the lead actor shows no character of a real Soldier. There is no combination of fear and valor whatsoever. He is made to look invincible until his death scene. Infact the movie was so into the bravery of Bikram that every other Soldier is portrayed as coward. This isn't how you win a war or you justify the contribution of a brave martyr.Initial battle scenes shows no military strategy, fear, or risk at all.And here comes the worst part: The final battle scene is so rushed as if the actual war had lasted for an hour or so and the story moves like the soldiers are going for some kind of picnic at a hill station. Plus it lacks the intensity of a realtime war where nearly 600 men died. Perhaps to show that less gore is primarily due to Director's ego to show less damage to the Indian military.All in all the movie seems like someone is telling me the story rather than living through the movie itself.Instead try watching Dunkirk or 12 strong. You will know how the real war is like.Karan Johar will absolutely make huge money with this movie by cashing into patriotism but it brings the quality of bollywood cinema fairly down.I'm giving 2stars for few average scenes here and there. Rest is completely irrelevant and forgettable.
Siddharth needs to work on his acting: john abraham or ajay devgn would have been better for this role. Movie lacked substance. Rest ok to watch .

No deep conversation with the family. Too much dialogues. Only last few minutes war scenes were watchable, but story ending was worst, too dramatic. Didnt feel anything after this movie.Reading wikipedia page about Captain Vikram Batra was more interesting and informative.Please stop making such movies if cant do justice for the characters.Do as usual rom com fictional movies. Its so disrespectful to characters in non fictional movies if the the movie is not done right.And why cant indian audience judge the quality of movie properly. 8.9? Seriously?

Everything is noteworthy in this film.Beginning with the storyline, it sticks to it cruz and doesn't deviate. Close to reality with a very minimal amount of fiction.Secondly the cast of the film. It's worth an applause. Everyone play their part so well. Not a single frame exists where you feel it is going ott. Not just Siddharth and Kiara but others as well. All the supporting characters also make a mark.Thirdly the album of this film. Every song is new. No remakes. Tunes are catchy. Originality clicks. Also they come into the movie at an appropriate situation making their mark. The Mann Bharraya sequence hits at the right note and unexpectedly. Every song is amazing and stays in your mind.The direction of the film is noteworthy. Every shot that is captured shows the vision of the director and his demand for that perfect shot. The amount of hard work put in and the vision of the director is very clear. The thought process of showing a particular thing in a particular manner is visible and is an evident factor why the final cut has come out so well.The next part, the cinematography of this film is so beautiful. The locations and shots make it so appealing to your eyes.Coming to the action sequences which are bang on. Choreographed well and filmed brilliantly. All are portrayed in a realistic manner and make you feel as if you are just present there in the moment and witnessing them live.The best part is the VFX. VFX made the film more attractive in a way that no where you feel it is caricaturish. Doesn't look dramatic at all.The dialogues are the most important ingredients in the film. They are written so well. Connecting aptly with the audience and making you feel as if they are being communicated to you.The screenplay is flowing in a beautiful manner. Every back and forth switch between the war and flashes from the past are in a perfect sync.Shershaah is a must watch for every movie lover since it has an element of everything you would love to see in a film apart from the fact that this was actually a real story and Capt. Vikram Batra had actually lived this life with his family, friends, colleagues and Dimple ofcourse.It has the perfect balance and blend of romance, emotions, patriotism, comedy, etc. And the best thing being no emotion or portrayal overpowers the other or takes over the other. They are all in proportion.Definitely a 10 rating film.

Review title: A life or two worth celebrating
Review_body: The Shershaah team did great justice in depicting Capt. Vikram Batra's life on screen, who was rather too good to be true in real life, because they were very honest in telling his story, no grand standing needed. At age 24, he had etched a fine example of being a Braveheart for his country, a son/brother one can be proud of for 2/3 lifetimes for his family. But I wish, he came back, if not for anyone else, for Dimple Cheema and saw her in that wedding outfit and set another rare example of a true love story that was lived. After watching the movie, all I could think of was her, who never got any official recognition, never wanted or sought anything, but has been living the life of another Braveheart quietly for last 20+ years. Her valor may not have been came to light in the battlefields but it certainly shown its true self, in her utter devotion in keeping their love story alive for these many years. Hats off to you Ms. Cheema.

SHERSHAAH is the story of a brave Indian soldier who laid down his life during the 1999 Indo-Pakistan war. Vikram Batra (Sidharth Malhotra) stays with his parents in Palampur, Himachal and his twin brother, Vishal Batra. Since the time he was a child, he was interested in joining the army. At college, he meets Dimple (Kiara Advani) and falls for her. She reciprocates his love and both start a relationship. At this point, Vikram decides to join the merchant navy instead of the army as it pays better. One day, when Vikram drops Dimple home, Dimple's father (Bijay J Anand) catches them red-handed. He tells Vikram that since he belongs to a different caste, he can't marry Dimple. Dimple, however, protests and even tells her father that Vikram would earn more than him since he's going to join the merchant navy. Meanwhile, Vikram starts getting second thoughts after his best friend Sunny (Sahil Vaid) insists that he should not give up his dream of joining the army. Vikram tells Dimple about his change of plans. This infuriates Dimple and she requests him not to make any more changes in future plans. Vikram then enrols himself at an army institute and passes with flying colours. In 1998, he gets his first posting at 13th Jammu and Kashmir Rifles at Sopore. Vikram is now a Lieutenant. His regiment comprises Lieutenant Sanjeev Jamwal (Shiv Panditt), Naib Sudebar Bansi Lal Sharma (Anil Charanjeett), Subedar Raghunath (Raj Arjun), Major Subrata Mukherjee (Abhiroy Singh) and Major Ajay Jasrotia aka Jassi (Nikitin Dheer), etc. In no time, Vikram proves his worth when he manages to capture a dreaded terrorist, Attaullah (David Browne), who's a part of the gang of an evil militant, Haider (Mir Sarwar). Vikram also befriends locals, unlike other soldiers. This proves to be of great help as a friendly local, Gafoor (Zahoor Zaidi), informs him that his son Arslaan (Afnan Ashia) has joined Haider's gang but wants to leave them. Meanwhile, Haider attacks 13th Jammu and Kashmir Rifles while they were moving as an act of revenge for capturing Attaullah. Naib Sudebar Bansi Lal Sharma loses his life in this attack. Arslaan helps Vikram as he tells the latter about Haider's hideout. In a risky operation, Vikram leads his team to the hideout and manages to capture and eliminate Haider. Before his death, Haider however warns Vikram that something big and devastating is going to happen soon. What happens next forms the rest of the film.

A film that topped my watchlist for a long time now, and I'm glad that I finally caught up with it.I don't remember when was the last Hindi film or even a film in the war genre which was so well-made, a film that ticks all the boxes and hits all the emotions there could possibly be.The last time a film in this genre was so refreshing to watch was Lakshya, and I feel this tops it in a lot of ways, even though both have their advantages and there's really no need to compare them.The biggest focal point of the film is Siddharth Malhotra, how good has he characterized Capt. Vikram Batra, the work that he has put in, and you can obviously see the outcome. If you weren't a fan already, after watching this, you sure will be.Kiara Advani was fantastic in her role as well, along with the other cast members. As the film proceeds, the writers and the director ensure to focus on each character, which makes you feel for them at various points in the film.As I said before, the film ticks all the boxes, right from the element of war and action, to the element of love, the background score and the music, the cinematography, everything is just right in this film. Brilliantly led from the front by the director, Vishnuvardhan. Overall, the film is fast-paced, plus you're invested in it right from the beginning, I couldn't find nor think of any flaws that would make the film less lovable.Shershaah is perfect. An exemplary example of a well-made war film, a Hindi film, a Siddharth Malhotra film. This film just took my breath away, so much so that even after 24 hours the film has definitely stayed with me and made a mark too. Couldn't recommend it enough.

There are only 2 reasons for writing this review. One - being a fellow technician in the film industry from another language (Kannada), the value & significance of how making a movie equaling a penance is not lost on me and the other - an acute lack of "film appreciation" by even the most mainstream reviewers.Not being one to watch movies based on reviews (where on the other hand, most people seem to form their opinions based on one and even decide whether to watch or not), I do go through them after in a bid to identify if grasping something was missed during my watch (the first watch is always to "feel the movie" and soak up the experience however, I do watch them again in case of compelling instances). The reviews by a few so-called mainstream reviewers seemed unduly harsh warranting this write-up.Let me try taking on a couple of common gripes from the scribes about SHERSHAAH.1. "Too similar to many other war movies"If a cricketers' biopic is made, it would be like saying "the cricketing aspects are too similar to ones found in other cricketers' biopic"!First things first, this is not a war movie. This is a BIOPIC and with the person being from the armed forces, war is a given. So, the backdrop is the most distinguished achievement of this individual, which was the Kargil war. As such, there is no getting away from the war zone. After all, the man is a martyr and at a tender age of 24 - when, most of us would still be trying to figure out how not to screw up our life!Technically, the film is very immersive during the war scenes. The locations, action, VFX and most importantly, the on-ground procedures followed are very impressive to say the least. Standing apart are the tactical gestures depicted, which clearly indicate that they have been thoroughly researched/consulted with. Such aspects are usually a casualty in the name of "cinematic liberty" as found in many other "so-called films made in India that are based on the armed forces or even the police". As such, a definite credit where it is due for sure.It is the camera work, editing and sound design that really takes one inside these scenes. Personally, for me, the RR (re-recording (mainly the BGM) was a mixed bag though.2. "The love story track"Yes, that is supposed to be an integral part of this movie since, the aim is to celebrate the man called Captain Vikram Batra. He is not a fictional character and hence, if he is shown sporting a smile, a bit of hair style, mannerism and a bit of persona that seems to mimic a certain Shar Rukh Khan then, that is reflective of the times he grew up in. If the on-screen love story seems to plain could the real life story be blamed for it? It need not be omitted for, that was the essence which kept the then adolescent chap's heart beating while safeguarding the nation's borders. Thankfully & correctly, things haven't been blown out of proportion to make it a "filmy romance".Coming to the good bits, a run time of 2 hours is a major plus. Also, the deliberate avoiding of "high pitched jingoism/Pak-bashing" by the makers is a relief too. There was a time when "Doodh maangogey toh kheer dengey, Kashmir maangogae toh cheer dengey" resonated with the audience however, an approach of dignified depiction works in favor of the movie here.Clear vision regarding the purpose of the movie is a good indication of the abilities/skills/craft of it's director. This clarity establishes that the most important language that a director should be aware of are the nitty-gritties of story telling. The makers need to be lauded for staying true to it through this effort.The point of cinema appreciation becomes relevant in such scenarios because, as viewers (general audience & reviewers alike), movies need to be watched for what they are and not what one "wants them to be". Yes, a reviewer can surely be constructive to indicate "what could have been" but surely not lose sight of what the movie is intended to be about in the first place. In that sense, SHERSHAAH is certainly an endeavor to authentically capture incidences visually that are documented in public domain with a mix of real life instances (which may not necessarily be too exciting). Being a biopic, it suffices if the family has found the movie to be graceful in saluting a martyr and true son of the nation. Together, we can all proudly say "Durge maata ki jai"!

Review title: An easy 10, perfect balance of Bollywood action with history
Review_body: It's quite rare for Indian movies with themes like this to maintain the balance between historic accuracy, classic Bollywood action and romance and avoid hyper nationalism but this just balanced every aspect perfectly.The war scenes aren't overdone in any way, blood and gore has been turned to absolute zero despite scenes that would suggest otherwise. Sounds and visuals beautifully composed to immerse the viewer into the environment.The dialogues were perfectly written to blend into the character of Captain Batra. One of the things I've noticed was Siddharth shaking his feet into a rhythemic, restless tapping- a trait of Captain Batra which Dimple Cheema described in an interview, the reluctance to sit idle, to tap the table with his hands and when told not to, tapping his feet.If someone is here for the love story, it is cute and nothing overblown. It plays an integral part towards the core plot and again doesn't feel out of place or forced into the plot.

The protagonist's identical twin is the narrator of the story but he, like the rest of the soldier's family, is relegated to the periphery of the plot, a creative decision that prevents Shershaah from becoming an overarching tale that straddles the exceptional courage of the martyr as well as the fortitude of his parents and siblings.The pace of course picks up with the action sequences. Cinematographer Kamaljeet Negi's camera captures the urgency and tension, a lot of scenes shot in dim lit frames convey how hostile the conditions are. These are parts that grip us, some we can't help but see with moist eyes. It's commendable that the tone remains steady and never loud and jingoistic.Best part is the climax with a surprise song!That, to a certain extent, is how the film is. Just a little more cinematic firepower and flint might have taken Shershaah much higher - and further - as a war drama.

Vikram Batra's life so the expectations was at another level and Sid has done full justice to that. But that goosebumps waala vibe was just not there.By just reading about Vikram Batra you will literally get goosebumps but in this movie that thing was missing. Whole field team did a great job indeed, Pranay, Shataf, shiv and especially his friend Sahil.But a big thanks for choosing Siddharth for this role as I believe nobody else could've done better than him. In that way, Kiara was also beautiful.PS. A one time watch.

Review title: A masterpiece portrayal of Indian Soldiers' pride and valor
Review_body: Not every Movie deserves appreciation, but this one needs to be given with more than just appreciation. At beginning of the film it seemed even this one was just an other such films focussing patriotism, but just as you commence forward you'll get a very huge perspective of a army person and making war isn't the best result of victory. War costs many brave lives and and no one chooses to loose their one and only life for the sake of nonviolence, so this movie has done a great job portraying the consequences of real life war and the immense loss of a family member and the cast of course have given their maximum to enact the actual person. After all we need to Respect our martyrs. Jai Hind.

I literally had my eyes glued to the screen. This movie is undoubtedly one of the best depicting "Kargil War times" and was top notch in every aspect.Capt. Vikram Batra is known for his tenacity, courage and indomitable spirit. He is role model for youth of 90s and specifically defence kids who lived during that period of Kargil War and lived the days in worry of our father.Siddharth Malhotra did a fantastic job and gave proper respect and justice with his acting to Capt. Vikram Batra, PVC. His acting, spirit was highly appreciable for sure. There was that spark, that tenacity, that spirit.Kiara was also very appropriate in terms of depicting Dimple ma'am.Their chemistry was so good overall.The BG scores of the movie were amazing.Hats off to B Praak and Jasleen for such beautiful
sountracks and such soothing melody.VFX were quite good too. Great job overall.I really wish bollywood to make one such movie on life of Lt. Manoj Kumar Pandey, PVC as well."Capt. Vikram Batra Amar Rahe"
"Lt. Manoj Pandey Amar rahe"
"Ye Dil Maange More"

Review title: Must awaited film by Sidharth Malhotra
Review_body: Shershaah is a 2021 Indian Hindi-language biographical war film directed by Vishnuvardhan in his Bollywood debut and written by Sandeep Shrivastava. The film follows the life of Param Vir Chakra-awardee Captain Vikram Batra, from his first posting in the army to his death in the Kargil War. The film stars Sidharth Malhotra as Batra and Kiara Advani as his girlfriend Dimple Cheema. The film was produced by Dharma Productions and Kaash Entertainment, with Hiroo Yash Johar, Karan Johar, Apoorva Mehta, Shabbir Boxwala, Ajay Shah and Himanshu Gandhi serving as co-producers.

Review title: A mediocre watch of a rather potential Blockbuster war flick
Review_body: Watch this movie for strong patriotic flavour, near realistic action scenes and amazing cinematography. Sid Malhotra's portrayal as the jolly yet fearsome war fighter Capt Vikram Batra was good. He has vastly improved in emoting to crucial scenes but somewhere I think that finesse was lacking. Kiara was OK. The rest of the cast members did their job fine to the extend they were given their respective roles Direction and lack of punchy dialogues are the achilis heels of this film. He had to put more emotions and up the suspense and thrill ante. This was my take on Shershaah. Now I know many of Sid Malhotra's fans and probably jingoist minded fans would bombard me with verbal abuses but one thing I want you all to know that I love the movie for a fitting Tribute to Late martyred captain Vikram Batra. No doubt in that. But taking into consideration about the other aspect of this film which is Entertainment-I have to say I am not satisfied fully rather to an extent disappointed. It was a mediocre watch.

This aspect is portrayed so well by Siddharth Malhotra who plays the sheet anchor in the film.The love story between Siddharth and Kiara Advani is slow and there is not much to say about it as it keeps dragging the film time and again. The emotional bonding between the family and lover of Vikram is not established well and does not move you emotionally.

Sidharth Malhotra starring Shershah achieves what it set out to achieve, monetize the story of an young army officer who bravely laid down his life for his country. The story line is linear and potrays the young officer as a monochromatic chracter whose only ambition is to go to war albeit being borderline insurbordinate and reckkless. The movie glosses over how his superior officers send his company out on back to back difficult mission without regard to troop wearout.The performance of the cast is 7/10 with requeried bollywood cliches and dance numbers. In the hands of a better director, the moview could have been about the tragedy of loss of life of a promising young man in the name of war but here it is glorified into a masala flick ready to mint box office gold. 4/10.

Review title: HEARTY LOVE FROM ARMY BRATS, MASTERPIECE!
Review_body:
One from the Army kid too! I already knew about the Kargil War with Capt Batra and his brotherly soldiers alongside, about their brave sacrifices and victory by our fathers and their fraternity. But still, Capt Batra's traits and charisma as we had learnt was excellently pulled off by Siddharth Malhotra to the maximum extent! The style, the Charisma, from a romantic filmy flair to this exceptionally brave fauji! Everything seemed so original! There was no too much fauji-giri or too much of romance. Everything on point. The action sequences, ambush scenes, defence/firing formations and ways too good. Other soldiers and officers of the battalion were also played very well! Great display of similarities. Dimple, uff, her innocence, originality, simplicity just everything made us fall for her. Dimple Cheema aka Mrs Batra is our unsung hero! Kiara was absolutely the best! The songs, damn. You still can't get over them. Right choice of the singer and music! The very fact that 99% of this movie is totally true makes us all cry and praise at the same time. I can bet you, if you can't survive last 20mins of the film without tearing up or goosebumps with a heavy heart.The best part I felt was, the makers really should be appreciated as they honoured the battalion's officers and soldiers who were a part of the war too!Just felt that the scenes especially the funeral ones, the ones with dimple or while Capt Batra watching the tricolour unfurled, could be a bit longer so as to give us a lil extra time to cope up with it allAll in all, this was one of the greatest, best, heart-touching films till date, I bet you won't be able to get over it so soon
From a fauji kid to you- always appreciate and remember what the soldiers sacrifice for you! It's just 1 film but narrates a thousand legacies of a thousand soldiers from our country.

Review title: A heart-wrenching tribute to Capt. Vikram Batra (PVC)
Review_body: This movie narrates the life story of the valiant Capt. Vikram Batra (PVC), who stood unflinching even in the face of death, all for his motherland. Sidharth did a terrific job as Capt. Vikram Batra. He carried himself extremely well and delivered a mighty impressive performance. The soundtrack was beautiful, with a few songs leaving you looking for tissues. The direction, of course, was fantastic. Some scenes left me crying and with goosebumps. That's just how good everything was. Kiara did a great job too. Towards the end of the movie, her performance is guaranteed to make you cry. The movie, as a whole, arouses a great feeling of patriotism in one's heart, besides taking you through heart-wrenching pain of the families of those valiant soldiers who proudly lay down their lives for the country, without so much as batting an eyelid. All in all, this movie is a must-watch. 10/10 go for it!

"FIKAR NA KAR JAANI, YA TO TIRANGA LEHRA KE AAUNGA YA USME LIPAT KR AAUNGA ......LEKIN AAUNGA JAROOR"
'SHERSHAAH' the story of such a devoted man, seeing whom the feeling of patriotism will be possessed for once in your heart and passion to do something for our country will be racked up. The 'SHERSHAAH' movie fabricated under the direction of Vishnuvardhan was released on 12th August, 2021 at the OTT platform of Amazon Prime Video in which the main cast of Captain Vikram Batra played by the very versatile actor Siddharth Malhotra.Vikram batra (9 September 1974 - 7 July 1999) was born in a middle class family of Palampur, a small district of Himachal Pradesh. From his childhood Vikram had the ambition to join the Indian Army. His love for Indian Army inspired him from a serial Paramvir Chakra which telecasted on Doordashahan and this reverence transfigured into a passion. He met with Dimple Cheema( role played by Kiara Advani , lead actress of film) in college and their love story transformed from friendship to marriage. Then he joined India army at the age of 23 after completing the training of one and half years at IMA as a lieutenant in 13 Jammu and Kashmir Rifles.This person's stubbornness to do something for the country and the definition of love in a right way has been showed to audience by the film Shershaah. From nonage, Vikram was always set to fight and take risks for his rights and this type of attitude aided him and Indian army in the Kargil War and in search operation of Kasmiri terrorist, Haider. He had a congenial behavior to his fellow soldiers and Kashmiris and this made him successful in completing many missions. The best thing about this movie for today's youth generation is when the Vikram decides to sacrifice his dream to join Indian Army for his love and then his friend, Sunny (role played by Sahil Vaid) told him the very right thing, "jab koi dusra banda aake sapna todta h na too banda sambhal jata h koi problem nhi hoti.........aur jab khud tu saare sapne todega na apne to aadmi mar jata h" and this words is for those teenagers who do anything for their love and don't know the wack consequences of it. Dimple Cheema said, "How do I describe a lifetime of memories, though made only in four years of association? I could go on and on, and the memories would still keep coming Not a single day in the past 17 years have I felt detached from you. It feels as if you are away on a posting. I know in my heart that we are going to meet again, it's just a matter of time" and that is the definition of love in real life in which you sacrifice everything for your partner but in a right way which have nothing bad impact on both.Siddharth Malhohtra acted all the dispositions of Vikram Batra in a very realistic way and he suited in this character very much. Shershaah was the name given to Captain Vikram for secret talk in Kargil War and that'why this film was named as SHERSHAAH. This film is a salute to that country lover who called "ye dil maange mor " as a victory sign which means he wanted to get these all enemies out of country, this is a salute to a soldier who is ready to lay down for Mother India at all times.I request you to watch this movie once and whoever has the slightest desire to do something for his country take inspiration and courage from the life of Param Veer Chakra awarded Captain Vikram Batra.

Review title: Best war film with a touching love story.
Review_body: You will feel every emotion while watching this movie.The action and war sequence have been shot exceptionally well, the CGI parts are also realistic, but the core of the film is the love story between Vikram and Dimple played by Sid and Kiaraa.Sid has played the part to the T. He is so believable as Vikram that you will feel you are watching the real story unfold. Without a doubt his best movie till date. I have always been a fan of Sid, but this movie made me fall in love with him.Kiaraa played Dimple with utmost honesty.The chemestry between Sid and Kiaraa made the movie believable.I have no shame to accept that I cried throughout the last 15-20 mins of the movie.Without a doubt, one of the best movies ever.

You are not acting in this movie, you are living it, and it is as if you are the Vikram Batra himself.Man, the highest appreciation for you. This is the first movie of you that I watch and you have captured my whole heart. THANK YOU for doing it so so so beuatifully. We couldnt ask for more. So blessed to see you here in this movie with Sid.My sincere thankful to the director and writer and Vikram Batra's family who has allowed Vikram Batra's stories to be published as beautifully as this. Like I cannot thank you all enough.Man, I have so many words, but I know this review could not even catch people's eyes, but I just wanna pour my feelings after watching this movie.THANK YOU!

Review title: A truly amazing movie in itself!
Review_body: After every few years, you come across a movie, which serves a lasting impact on you. Mentally and emotionally, it teaches you something or inspires you.Shershaah is one of those movies. Never have I ever felt a surge of patriotism in me. I think last patriotic movie which all of us remember is Uri: the surgical strike.Shershaah is totally realistic and original. I thought some of the plots might have been taken from Uri, but I was wrong. This movie is very original in itself.The one thing which I really loved about it is that it not only shows the brave and audacious side of a soldier but also the human side of him.The location, the storyline, the casting, the songs, the way the movie flows and holds its audience till the very end, is just brilliant!!The cast has also played their roles very beautifully. Sidharth Malhotra, though an underrated actor in Bollywood has done a great job! And the way he has performed shows that he really did put in his sweat and blood to bring out the true character of Captain Vikram Batra. Even, Kiara Advani has played the role very beautifully. I can't even imagine anyone else playing the role of Dimple Cheema other than Kiara.Over all a great masterpiece!!

Review title: "Ye Dil Maange More" - Captain Vikram Batra (PVC)
Review_body: Each and every scene of this movie is so perfectly put together and so realistic. It is so beautiful and inspiring and it gives you a feel as if you're really there. All the songs are so beautiful and full of emotions. You feel all the lyrics and you get every feeling, whether it be love or courage or admiration, and it's amazing! Absolutely amazing! The music and their acting makes it seem as if you lived every moment with the characters and that shows just how authentic it is. Both lead actors have nailed it with their characters. They couldn't have chosen a better actor for Captain Vikram Batra's role, as Sidharth Malhotra portrays it perfectly with both his dialogues and the mannerisms. Kiara Advani has also done a wonderful performance in this movie as lead actress and I hope to see more of Sidharth and Kiara's chemistry on screen.And of course, Salute to the real Captain Vikram Batra and his real-life story that is being brought to the big screen. This is such an inspiring story full of courage and bravery and will certainly stay with me for the rest of my life.This is the best movie I have ever watched and this film will always have a special place in my heart. Hats off to Director Vishnu Varadhan, Writer Sandeep Shrivastava, Producer Karan Johar, and all others who have contributed to the making of this film. No amount of words can fully express how I feel about this film but I hope this sums it up well. Please go and watch this amazing masterpiece if you haven't already and show your love for India. You won't be disappointed!

Review title: Perfect movie. Watched something after a long time which stayed with me.
Review_body: An amazing movie to watch. Hats off to the valour and courage Captain Vikram Batra had. I am very moved by his story. Coming to the movie...Siddharth played Vikram's character flawlessly. I started feeling as if he is a real soldier. He did commendable job. Kiara also acted well. The last scene when she cries seeing last rites of Vikram Batra is extremely touching. Most importantly the movie is not just about KARGIL. Its actually about Vikram Batra's journey. Some people may say that first half is slow but that pace was necessary to build his character especially, portraying how he turned from a civilian to a lieutenant to a captain to a martyr. The best part of movie is that its not at all masala movie. Its actually a realistic as well as emotional movie.

Review title: One of the best Bollywood biopic.
Review_body: There are many biopics in Bollywood but the stand out movie till now for me was Bhag Milkha Bhaag. But now Shershaah is winning the race according to me. The movie is very well directed and very precise. I can't even think about he efforts the team took to do the research and present it so beautifully on the screen. And Sidharth Malhotra damn he was fab, I can't imagine any other actor other than Sidharth playing Captain Vikram Batra. I hope Sid will keep taking such roles in future and keep proving him as an actor (as a fan I'll love him anyway).

Film Review of ShershahThe first thing that springs to mind as Shershaah unfolds is this: a war hero deserved a far more engaging and energetic film. It is a suitably solemn, restrained account of the brief life and career of a 25-year-old Army Captain who died fighting in the 1999 Kargil war, but it takes inordinately long to get anywhere near full throttle. Shershah is a biopic movie dedicated on the life of the brave Indian soldier Late Captain Vikram Batra, an inspiring war drama of bravehearts and victories. It is one of the best war realistic films ever made in Bollywood. The film was released on 12th August 2021 on the OTT Platform Amazon Prime. The film consisted of Siddharth Malhotra as Captain Vikram Batra, Kiara Advani as Dimple Kapadia, Ankita Goraya as Nutan Batra, Raj Arun as Subhedar Raghunath Singh, Shiv Pandit as Army captain etc. The 2hrs 15 minute film was directed by Vishnuvardhan, Produced by Dharma Productions Karan Johar.Talking of the story, The Kargil conflict - the toughest mountain warfare ever. Fought at a dizzying altitude of 17,000 feet, this historic war had a lot at stake. The Pakistani troops had infiltrated into the Indian side of the LoC, disguised as Kashmiri militants. The skirmishes quickly escalated into a full-blown war that also chalked the journey of a soldier from Lieutenant to Captain for his absolute dare-devilry and patriotic spirit to unfurl the tricolour at the highest point of conflict. Even if that meant laying down his own life for the cause. But before we get there, director Vishnu Varadhan and his writer Sandeep Srivastava take it slow. So we are taken right back to a childhood sequence of Captain Vikram Batra (Sidharth Malhotra) and shown his growing up years, finding the love of his life Dimple Cheema (Kiara Advani), before he is finally posted at the 13 JAK Rifles as a Lieutenant. I won't be revealing the full story to spoil your mood.The film was a total justice to an army man's life. The film showed how the army is committed for the safety of Kashmir people, countering the terrorists, gathering inputs, the coordination, teamwork and how brave our army men are. Film was mainly shot in Kashmir and I was stunned by the way the film was shot and edited, especially the gun scenes and the way it was shot at high altitudes. It was incredible. The songs of these movies were so soothing and lovely that I can't express my words. Raataan Lambiyan by Jubin Nautiyal and Ranjha by B Praak were so good that it became an instant hit while Instagram was flooded with reels of these 2 songs. The film even had a touch of romance of Siddarth Malhotra and Kiara Advani for which bollywood is famous. I felt personally that the way Siddharth Malhotra acted in this biopic was truly the best. The way he delivered the dialogues like "Dil Mange More," "Live by chance, love by choice and kill by profession" were epic.The film's overall tone is obviously high on patriotism. Many combat scenes don't reflect the large canvas that the film is set up on, perhaps more deserving of a big screen experience. Yet, as an industry, Bollywood has seldom churned out epic war films that have been critically and commercially acclaimed. By those standards, 'Shershaah' ranks higher than most of the recent war dramas and tells an inspiring story that needs to be told.The source material of this film is so strong that it is bound to grip you once the men in uniform take it upon themselves to drive out the enemy and reclaim our land. 'Shershaah's biggest victory is its effort to recreate one of the most important chapters of our recent history with characters, who lead the way to a rousing climax. For me this film is a 5 on 5.

Review title: Pls Avoid...an insult to Capt Batra.
Review_body: Such a lovely topic so poorly handled. Trust Karan Johar to bring romance and drama in a story that should be handled exclusively for the substance that the main subject of the movie should bring. The movie failed to inspire as it should have and it was a drag in the middle.The character building for the protagonist missed highlighting critical aspects of how Capt Batra joined NCC and was adjudged the best NCC Air Wing Cadet of Punjab and later was promoted to Senior Under Officer (SUO) and subsequently was selected for the Republic Day Parade (which is a matter of great honour) all leading upto his decision to join the Indian Army. However, he has been shown as a 'happy-go-lucky' guy who nurtures this boyish dream to join the army without any disciplined efforts towards that, which is of course not the case. Vikram (not then captain) trying to get liquor only meant for the army, was so misplaced and seemed so disjointed as a scene. Looked like it just had to be crammed in. Important aspect of character building was missed where he went for a commando course to Belgaum and got the highest grading possible and excelled in it. Clearly a part of character building, which has been ignored in favour of showing some other drama and romancing.The movie is factually wrong on minor accounts and for a biopic, it is unforgivable. Not sure how Capt Batra's family accepted some of these fallacies, if at all permission was sought from them.All in all, this movie, while a poor attempt, is an insult to a soldier like Capt Batra. Could have been made so much better, with the right intent.This move is avoidable and if you want to see a movie which has the capacity to inspire, watch 'Lakshya' or 'Prahaar'.

He gets overly enthusiastic on war which is actually the last think a soldier wants, unless he is on for a suicide. Weak story, weak direction and weak reality.

Review title: It 101% justified the sacrifice of PVC Captain Vikram Batra
Review_body: Hardwork of 5 years by team paid off. Salute to director VishnuVaradhan direction and acting by Siddharth and Kiara. When movie starts, it takes you to final battle scene and then it takes you to life of PVC Batra starting from his childhood with his twin brother and shows how he was patriotic since his childhood. Movie captures terror incidents in J&K and followed by Batra returns to his love for short period and during which Kargil war starts. His final good bye to his love gives goosebumps. He then posted in area where heavy bombing happens from Pakistan which kills his knows seniors. That incident triggers his battalion to engage in Kargil War. Review title: Best portrayal of Warfare movie in Hindi Cinema

When the Shershaah's trailer came, I was very much impressed with that. The movie came out and people gave it great reviews making me more eager to watch it. I had only one question, that would it be able to surpass the near perfect standard set by Lakshya, who inspired thousands to join Army. The first scene of the movie itself reminded me of lakshya. Starting from the kargil, the movie went to college days. The movie progressed almost like lakshya. The movie didn't lost it's momentum at any point. The battle scenes and Army discipline was what I missed in the movie. Sidharth did good but was bit dull in comparison to Hritik in lakshya and even to vicky kaushal of Uri. The background score was also not so inspiring. The casting director also didn't gave importance to the actors for supporting cast and had an average supporting cast. But one thing I liked more in this movie, I.e., Army is not only about officers, it's also about jawan and the director showed it.Overall, I will say it's a watchable movie which is all about gunfire but nowhere near Lakshya, a masterpiece.

Review title: Yeh dil mange more is line that many of us would like to say for this movie!!
Review_body: Shershaah an epic movie (biopic) about the life of Capt. Vikram Batra. Well this movie gave justice to his story. Many were complaining about love angle of this movie from trailer and that shows the lack of research done by the audiences about our great hero Cpt. Vikram Batra. This movie is first biopic and war genre. And Capt. Batra 's romantic life is essential part of it, so it will obviously be there. Coming to the movie Sidharth Malhotra was extremely promising as Capt. Vikram Batra which shows that he obviously has more than his looks . This is his turning point of carrier and I hope he chooses more out of zone characters to play. Kiara Advani was also promising. The thing were she lacked for me was her punjabi accent and fluency. It was good but not as promising as I was expecting it to be. But overall she was great too. This movie has some interesting cast choices and I liked it. Actors were quiet similar looking to its real life person which was good they all did there jobs well. Another thing I liked about this movie is its sound design. Sound designers did great job. Vfx were also nice. Thing that impressed me about vfx was muzzle effect and grenade. Vfx guys have done there research. Literally most Indian movies have got these things wrong. Fight choreography was also nice. Only place were it got fucked was in fight scene with haider those puches really looked fake. That was the one of the little faults that I found in this movie. Overall great film definitely must watch. Hands-off to all actors and crew members for making this great film.

About the story:
Many people consider this movie a masterpiece. Don't know why. Whenever you are making a biopic of a real life hero, it not necessary to make it crispy or more dramatic as if it is a fictional story. The script should be written in a way that a viewer gets more information about the main character on whose life the movie is being made and his/her surroundings. This whole movie is made to make to make the audience emotional, sentimental by the songs. How you can say that a movie is masterpiece biopic when the makers are getting cuss words out of main lead's mouth (Sidharth Malhotra as Captain Vikram Batra). Does these kind of scenes really make a real life hero a hero as he was is real life.About the acting:
Sidharth Malhotra's acting was not good enough as it was required but Kiara Advani's performance was somehow good. The actors were really poor at speaking Punjabi. Vikram Batra, on whose life the movie is about, was a Punjabi and Sidharth Malhotra who portrayed his character didn't even had the basic accent to speak Punjabi on screen. The actors could have done some workshop on this matter. The supporting actors (Shiv Panditt, Sahil Vaid, Nikitin Dheer, Mir Sarwar, Raj Arjun etc) were good at their work.About the VFX:
The VFX was not really a great thing in this particular movie. Some scenes were good in terms of VFX but some were really a disaster. Can't say anything much about the VFX since it was just normal (not looking too real). URI had 10 times better VFX sequences in terms of action, fighting scenes, gun shots, background etc.
Yess yeh dil mange more, kudos to the team for great efforts. Hard work paid off.Just watch it. Trust me you won't regret it. Sid was just amazing, by far one of the great performance by sid.

This film has done a great job capturing bravery and Vikram Batra and Indian Army officers and soldiers. Its a very inspiring movie and helps highlight that the freedom that we enjoy everyday comes at the cost of the blood that our soldiers shed at the borders for us. Jai Hind!

A good war film leaves one with fostering disgust for war. But Sheershah glorifies war, it even has a moment where Siddharth Malhotra say's "Har fauji ka sapna hota hain kam se kam ek baar war mein janeka mauka mile". Ik this is not exactly glorifying war but I'm pretty sure that no soldiers walks and serves with carrying that as a desire. Film has nothing to offer which ain't been already served, there are ample of articles about Capt. Batra which has more to offer than this film, this film is no doubt a subdued tribute to Capt. Batra. The elements of Capt. Batra 's life had so much potential for multi-layered storytelling but 'Sharshan' missed it's shot. The war front sequences were good especially the first hill recapturing, as it had lil details to offer but the rest were mediocre at it's best.
